A year ago, we closed on our home! A quirky house set on 12 acres in the woods of Maine. 

Thanks for joining us in the ups & downs of first time homeownership…the ups being things like Minka & Boone in never ending zoomies around the yard, & the downs being things like losing heat & power during a snowstorm the day we closed. 😅

It’s been a steeeeep learning curve in owning a home & stewarding the land we’re on. Yet, we are immensely grateful to have the opportunity to do so & certainly do not take that responsibility lightly! Even before we starting dating, Isaac & I had the shared desire of owning land for the sole purpose of sharing it with others. We wanted to crate a place to extend hospitality, spoil loved ones with fun experiences & offer peaceful respites.

And here we are, 10 years later, doing the damn thing! Without exaggeration, we hosted guests every single weekend from the day we moved in, mid January through early May and then July through October. (I’ve never made so many beds nor willingly vacuumed in my life lololol.) Hosting like this just wasn’t conducive in our old 500sq ft. apt & we are so freaking stoked to be to able to now comfortably accommodate anyone who visits. It’s our hope that our home continues to be a rad destination for years & years to come…& that our tiny house, forest & hot tub continue to entice all the guests.

Another dream come true has been enjoying visits from so many animals: Foxes, deer, turkeys, a bear, a moose, bald eagles, and countless birds, chipmunks & squirrels! Fingers crossed the list keeps growing & that that mama fox decides to raise her kits here again this spring!

Anywayyyy thanks for coming along on this wild ride & cheering us on through a myriad of big life changes. We so appreciate you being here! 🌲

(Big thanks to our friends &
@dirtandglass & @heypamcakes capturing these photos of us in celebration of this anniversary!)

Take a trip down memory lane to every iteration of Stone Collector Pendants past…💎

These photos begin with the raw gems that I am currently crafting into new pendants. Then they travel all way from my most recent batch in 2022 back to the originals I crafted when I first started metalsmithing in 2016. I’ve gone from turquoise in bezel settings to raw gems in prong settings. It’s fascinating to see how my skills & style have evolved over the years!

Yet, the one thing that hasn’t changed over the years is how my joy & inspiration is as replete as the stones I collect. My house is filled with stones of all kinds, each representing a memory from a hike, trip, moment or location. Momentos of precious time spent outdoors with those I love doing what I love!

Needless to say, I am beyond elated to have one more collection to offer you of these necklaces Thursday, 12/15 at 7pm EST. They’ll include all the stones pictured in the first photo! Now, which pendant(s) were your favorite from years’ past? 💎

This isn’t just a hemlock cone necklace- it holds a much deeper meaning…

After I was released from the hospital & was diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder back in 2018, it took me a while to be well enough to get out on the trails again. Med changes & their side effects were rough, leaving me inside for a long time. When I was able to hike again without nausea, it felt like I was on the trails for the very first time. It was magical- the forest heals. On that hike, I collected some hemlock cones along the way. I still wasn’t able to work at my bench for a prolonged period of time due to headaches (took 3 months until I could fire up my torch again) so instead, I decided to try my hand at organics casting. With a friend, I took those cones and cast them in Sterling & then took my favorite pinecone & creates that very first, now signature, hinge setting.

I work that necklace every day that year as I navigated the difficult journey of coming to terms with and managing my diagnosis. It came with me on my daily hikes, up in the white mountains when I was able to ski again, all over the west on a road trip, to our month long trip to Patagonia & all over New England. It served as a talisman- a daily reminder that if a tiny hemlock cone, in time could grow into a giant, majestic Hemlock tree, then I too would be able to grow & eventually flourish as a person with BPD II.

So, I decided to make this a core piece of jewelry. You see, this isn’t JUST a hemlock cone- it’s a personal reminder that you are as strong, resilient & deeply rooted as the tall trees in the forest. I’ll have a hearty handful of these tree talismans available on Thursday, 12/15 at 7pm EST.

I’ll be sharing more of my Bipolar Disorder journey soon- I haven’t really gotten personal on here in a while, and at the end of the day, genuine connection is more important to me that jewelry. Thank you for being here & being open to receiving a bit of my story. 🤍🌲

On this day 7 years ago I took my very first metalsmithing class! 🤯💎

I had a demanding full time job & missed expressing my creativity, so I took the class on a whim. And upon 1st ignition of that torch, I fell in love.

Then in early 2016, I quit my job to pursue this metalsmithing endeavor I called The Wild Pine. And here we are 6 years later! What a rad ride it’s been. So, I thought it would be fun to take a jaunt down memory lane & look at all of the FIRSTS:

1: Getting to create my dream studio ever in our first home.

2: First time firing up a torch in 2015 at @metalwerxstudio!

3: First pendant & silver band I ever crafted, with the very first piece of natural turquoise I bought & saved years prior.

4: First studio: a 3x7ft nook in our tiny apartment that served me for 2 years!

5: First full week being self employed in May 2016, with the tiniest baby Minka coworker!

6: First multi-stone ring I crafted in my 1st studio.

7: First trip to the Tucson Gem show!

8: First pair EVER of Mountain Maven Ear Jackets in 2016.

9: First pine pendant I created that I was truly proud of in June 2016.

10: First time Minka ever balanced turquoise! #minkanosebest

And lastly, here are words I wrote back in 2016 reflecting upon “firsts.” They feel especially fitting for today:

“This ring is very special as it represents a beginning: the start of fulfilling a lifelong dream to pursue art as vocation. After leaving my full time job, I was so afraid that I had made the wrong decision- that I was crazy to chase after something that was so beyond my degree and experience. This ring (pic 6) was one of the 1st pieces I made in my own studio, with my own tools as I began TWP. It marks a lot of firsts, really- 1st time working with turquoise, 1st time sawing without breaking a blade, 1st time making a split ring shank, & 1st time bringing my own design to fruition. I was so happy when I finished it- creating it felt so natural that I knew that I had made right decision. So, go pursue that thing that you‘ve always dreamt of, no matter how crazy it may seem- when you have passion & faith, all else will fall into place.”
They could jump off a cliff & I’d still blindly follow.

TGIF. Are you more of a Boone or a Minka?! 🤪

ALSO: Surprise! Just restocked some of your favorite jewels in my shop!! Grab them before they’re gone! Everything will ship & arrive before Christmas!

(Swipe for the best thing you’ll see all week.)

Surprise! Filled my shop’s shelves AGAIN with little woodland talismans. Seems that the holiday spirit has taken me & productivity is at an all time high, so, why not keep going?!

(Especially when I can marathon New Girl whilst crafting. Dream job. 😆) 

UPDATE: hemlocks sold out, but I have plenty of Pinecone Hoops and Pine Tree Medallions in the shop!

Happy perusing & wishing you a wonderful weekend!!

HOW TO support creators & small business owners this holiday season!

(Other than purchasing their amazing wares, of course!)

It’s MORE IMPORTANT than ever to:
1. LIKE, COMMENT, SHARE & SAVE posts

2. Comments are the most impactful, as they enable you to truly connect with the makers behind the squares.

3. Share a post to your story with a little blurb of why it struck you or why you love it.

4. Tap the bell in the upper right hand corner of a creator you love- it will help you see their posts more frequently.

5. Snooze “suggested posts” to unclog your feed & enable you to actually see what you want to see. 

6. Save posts you love- it shows the algorithm what quality content you want to go back to.

7. Slide into DMs & simply offer kind words/encouragement!

8. Recommend their shop/insta to a friend or family member. Word of mouth goes super far!

9. If you know them personally, send them a little something- whether it be an encouraging text, a nice note or a venmo for a coffee!

And lastly, a huge thank you for being here & shopping small this holiday season. It means the world to us artists & makers, as it’s your support that keeps us going.

To all of your fellow creatives- I raise my glass to you. Cheers to being in the home stretch! Keep on keeping on. We got this! 💪🏼🎉

You may be wondering why I haven’t offered my Mountain Maven Ear Jackets in a while…truth is, I’ve been majorly burned out on them. I really did it to myself earlier this year, biting off way more than I could chew. They’re the most tedious thing I make, and after crafting a batch of 50 sets over the course of two months (400 stones set by hand 😅), I swore I’d never make them again.

So, took some time to focus on new designs and filled my cup with creativity once again. ANDDDD that brings me to a little announcement: I’ll be offering a very small, limited batch of these made-to-order Kingman ear jackets tomorrow at 7pm EST. They won’t ship in time for Christmas, BUT, will be to you just in time for the new year. NYE ear jackets anyone?

Anyway- thank you for supporting me as a creator & for cheering all of us artists on throughout our ebbs and flows. Hope to see you tomorrow! ✌🏼

Gem Collector’s Pendants
✨
I’ve told of their meaning before, but wanted to do so again as imbuing stories into my work is the most important to me: After a memorable excursion or transformative experience in the wilderness, I procure a lovely little rock from each place to serve as a memento. They now all reside in a dish on our coffee table. Pouring over these simple, yet meaningful stones brings me back to those happy memories. A tiny red rock from my first camping trip as an 11-year-old, a green rock from the cove in which I experienced peaceful solitude, a striped rock from a wilderness trip in college where I met my best friend, and even a rock from the Pictured Rocks cliffs where Isaac proposed to me. Each serves as a sort of "trail marker" for a significant time in my life...this was my inspiration behind these pendants.
✨
Each necklace features unique cuts of high quality stones & crystal specimens, mined all over the world: Tourmaline, Kunzite, Mexican Fire Opal, Vanadinite, Citrine & Amber. I crafted each into "collection" like settings, intentionally choose mismatching stones- no two are alike, just as in nature. Each hangs at 16” and extend to 18”. They were made to become your “trail markers”- necklaces to celebrate a momentous occasion or to simply serve as reminders of the amazing natural beauty of this earth.
✨

Last Xmas vs. This Xmas 😅🎄

Merry Crisis! As you know, I have been eagerly anticipating the 1st Christmas in our new home. Like most of the country, we were hit with ice, snow, sleet, rain & single digit temps this week, knocking out our heat and power. So instead of getting to chop down our own Christmas tree in a idillic gentle snowfall, we had the privilege of panic chopping down a tree that had fallen on our power lines in freezing rain. 😆

The holiday cheer continued as we patched a hole in the roof in said sleet, battled our septic system (which decided to come INSIDE 😫) aaaaand rage chopped/removed thick ice that encased our driveway. Isaac & I oddly thrive in times of crisis, and cope with dark humor. The wild weekend has given us some pretty killer inside jokes & unique holiday memories.

We were JUST lamenting that we didn’t go camp as much as we wanted this summer, but we were so generously provided with the full experience inside our home for over 24 hours! We cooked over one propane burner, ran the generator in shifts, played a rousing game of trivia, & puzzled away under the light of an oil lamp. But the best by far was finding a cache of glow sticks in a drawer. We decked out the huskies, engaged rave mode, & let them go wild in the house. 😎

Even though circumstances threw us for a loop, I’ll always remember this Christmas fondly. Power was restored yesterday, & while we had the opportunity to take a “nice” family photo in front of our tree, we decided that this wet & bedraggled shot of us and the dogs was perfect. Christmas 2022.

We are beyond grateful for our home and the privilege of stewarding a slice of land here in Maine - freezing rain or shine. Should losing power become the first newly established holiday tradition?? 😆

Anyway, Merry Christmas from our fam to yours- hope yours turned out to be as cozy & memorable as ours. 🥰🎄

We weren’t ready for the 1st Christmas in our new home to be over…

So we’re extending it all month long! Taking an unintentional break from work & hibernating after the hustle & bustle of the season has been even more needed than anticipated. So, thank you for allowing us to relish in the quietness a while longer. Remember, nothing in nature blooms all year, so be kind to yourself as you embark upon 2023! 🥰

Don’t let the good be the victim of the perfect.

I’ve had a rough few weeks internally. I was very spoiled last year as I experienced little to no anxiety. In fact, 2022 was one of the best years of my life. I practically forgot that I have Bipolar Disorder. However, I’ve been unfortunately reminded after the comedown from the holiday season & the beginning of a new year. In juggling so many things, my mind has turned into an anxious, overstimulated & overwhelmed mess. While I have so many good things happening behind the scenes as well, it’s felt safe to keep things buttoned up, hence my sporadic quietness on here.

While I can name the triggers & am equipped with an entire arsenal of things that help (therapy, meds, friends, family, nature, self care) I’ve allowed my cruel internal monologue to paralyze me the past week.

Everyone, with or without neurodivergency, experiences bouts of overwhelming anxiety throughout life. We each have developed a myriad of ways to manage it, in both positive & negative ways. My preferred (unhealthy) coping mechanism is extreme perfectionism. 

Everything I do, be it cleaning the kitchen, polishing jewelry, texting back, posting on Instagram, answering DMs, seeing old friends, making new friends, or connecting with family needs to be done just right. Perfectly. If I can’t do it “perfectly” then I simply don’t do it. Or, procrastinate. Or- even better- I do it, yet criticize myself the entire time I’m doing it. 

A few years ago, I was on the edge of tears scrubbing a pan. It wasn’t about the pan- it was the giant accumulation of tiny internal failures threatening to bury me. Isaac, cognizant of my internal tension, lovingly intervened: “Honey, put the pan down, it’s clean enough. It’s ok. Don’t let the good be the victim of the perfect.”

A simple, yet powerful phrase finally silenced my ruthless inner voice. My irrational insufficiency was swept away & relief took its place.

It has become my mantra. I repeat it to myself often in times like these. So, I’m claiming it as my theme for 2023. And if you’re in the same boat, you can adopt it too: Don’t let the good be the victim of the perfect. 🤍

Do you ever feel like you have so many ideas and interests and potential plans and exciting possibilities and cool things on the horizon and attainable dreams and achievable goals but you just sit and stare and let both the positive and negative overwhelm of it all wash over so you make absolutely no progress towards any of it for an entire day(s)?!?!

As you may or may not know, my husband, Isaac & I love skiing. We each grew up on skis & a board, so it naturally became our favorite activity to do together. In 2019 we stumbled across the idea of ski touring as a new way to explore places off the beaten path of expensive ski resorts.

At the time, we found it difficult to locate affordable & inclusive resources to get started. We pieced together what we needed, scouring the internet, watching Youtube videos, & renting gear a few times to teach ourselves. Ski culture historically includes a bit of gatekeeping, so not having friends or family who already enjoyed backcountry skiing was another obstacle. However, even through the fumbling, blisters, & feeling stupid at times, our joy for the sport eclipsed the awkwardness. Over the past 5 seasons we have slowly met new friends & introduced old ones to backcountry skiing. It’s been so FUN! It’s amazing to watch the ski community in the Northeast grow, flourish & change for the better.

So, does this sound familiar? Do you too want to dip your toes in but have no clue where to begin?! Wellll I am beyond excited to introduce you to a solution: @inclusiveskitouring!

It’s a rad nonprofit here in New England that aims to create a positive and inclusive space for anyone looking to try ski touring or split boarding!

It too welcomes seasoned experts looking to connect in the ski community. There are weekly programs specifically designed for women, underrepresented athletes & basically anyone who feels like they “don’t belong” in uphill skiing or split boarding. It’s a low pressure environment, that comes at little to no cost, & is a blast!

I am stoked to be leading a few tours this season (see you at the Women’s tour Saturday!) & am beyond thrilled for the rest of our volunteer team who are passionate about helping get folks on the slopes.

Will you join us?! Head to the IST website to learn more & sign-up, or consider a donation to help keep this nonprofit organization running! Hope to see you out there!! -Laura

If I were to create a Venn Diagram to represent my current state of mind, one side would read “skiing”, the other “smithing” & the center: “pine trees.”

Let me explain: when I’m not in the studio sawing & soldering swathes of silver pines, I’m skiing through striking stands of silhouetted pines.

So, for my next collection, I decided to marry the three loves of my life: Introducing the Firs & First Tracks Collection, coming mid February.

It will be chock full of wintry pines, ski motifs & general frosty merriment. I will be revisiting this one-off ring I crafted many moons ago with silver “ski tracks.” I’ve spent years collecting a bevy of Black Buffalo Turquoise specifically sliced into black diamonds & double black diamonds: a nod to the steepest ski trails. And, as you may remember, I have a hearty handful of natural Dendritic Agates that look EXACTLY like frosty firs.

Needless to say, after a month full of skiing & smithing behind the scenes, I am beyond inspired. I cannot wait to bring all of the pieces swirling in my head to fruition…More details to come. 🌲⛷️❄️

“Nothing in nature blooms all year. Be patient with yourself.”

If you’re like me & it feels like it’s taken longer to get back in the “groove” this year, adopt this as your personal motto.

I find myself revisiting this quote every Winter; a season both exhilarating & exhausting. As someone who is constantly pushing myself to be better, do better, create better & relate better, it’s a good reminder that all good things come with time. Patience is progress. Play is progress. Rest is progress. (Skiing is progress! 😉)

My “progress” for today was creating a little bricolage of gemstones. This simple assemblage of beautiful things was a great way to reset creatively. It sparked much joy & inspiration amidst a very busy day.

So, what did “progress” look like for you today?

Sending you all the love & encouragement as you navigate this season too…All the way from snowy Maine.🤍

These golden pine silhouettes upon the snow 🤍🌞

I’ve never seen a sunrise quite so stunning in my entire life- inspiration abounds in the Sierras, & I can’t wait to take this & translate it into silver my next collection. 🌲

ARE YOU GOING TO TUCSON?!

I’m not. 😭

I traded the Tucson Gem Show for skiing in Tahoe with my fam, so I absolutely can’t complain- skiing & metalsmithing are my two greatest loves. However, I definitely miss my annual pilgrimage to Arizona. The gem show feels like a giant staff party, where I get to connect with fellow metalsmiths, shop for stunning stones & galavant through the cacti with friends. DEF going next year! In the meantime, here’s 
 a trip down memory lane from Tucson trips past. 💎🌵

SO I have a favor to ask…
It’s my birthday tomorrow, & it would meant the WORLD to me if you took me along on your gem show and/or outdoorsy excursions! If you were or are in Tucson, OR if you’re outside & see a cool rock/tree, SHOW ME! Being tagged in or sent gratuitous gem & pinecone pics is all I could ever want for my bday! 😆 Y’all are the best. 

#seeagemsendagem
#seeapineconesendapinecone

Believe it or not, these are completely natural agates with “pine” inclusions! Nature mirroring nature.🌲

Ever since I began metalsmithing 7 years ago, I’ve been on the hunt for stones that resemble evergreens. I’ve slowly collected these stunning Montana agates dendritic agates over the years, that look EXACTLY like my beloved conifers. I am elated to FINALLY have a bevy of these magical stones, so my next collection of jewelry will be dedicated to showcasing their majestic, wintry beauty.

Previews of pieces begin later this week, with the full Firs & First Tracks Collection releasing on February 23rd at 7pm EST. I can hardly wait! 🤍🌲

Effortlessly modeling gems & jewels since 2016. 🤯💎 #minkanosebest

Been a while since we featured Minka in all of her good girl glory! Today she’s showing off these STUNNING natural slices of Black Buffalo Turquoise for my upcoming collection. I’ve been on the hunt for these very specific stones in very specific shapes for very specific jewelry for YEARS now...& I’ve finally sourced & cut them!! Each is specifically cut to mirror Black Diamond and Double Black Diamond symbols that represent the toughest, steepest, most exhilarating ski trails.

This collection is dedicated to all the badass babes out there shredding the slopes…both on & off piste. Each stone is destined to become jewelry to remind you of your most badass skiing self in the form of necklaces, studs & rings.

Photo dump of the BEST ski season I’ve had to date so far…featuring the bevy of badass babes I’ve been fortunate enough to shred with this winter!

I just recently realized that I’ve hit the slopes with more women this winter than in all of my 27 years of skiing combined! I’m wildly grateful to have FINALLY tapped into a community of like-minded ladies who love to engage in extreme winter sports together- in New England & beyond. Here’s to many more sessions of SKIING LIKE GIRLS this season! ⛷️💃🏼

(And a big shoutout to @inclusiveskitouring  for specifically creating spaces to bring women together on the snow. If you want to join the growing ski community here in New England yet don’t know where to start, be sure to check us out!)

How many pinecones are too many pinecones?! Trick question cause THE LIMIT DOES NOT EXIST.

Major CHANGE of plans tonight- we are giving the people what they want & pivoting to Pinecone Necklaces! 💃🏼🌲

Why? Well, I decided to postpone my ski inspired collection- ironically bc of skiing. We have a big & exciting ski trip coming up next week (more on that soon 👀) & I’ve been putting in long hours behind the scenes training for it & coordinating a few rad projects with a cool org & some outdoor brands (like I said, EXCITING STUFF!) Needless to say, I haven’t had the mental bandwidth to fully be present at the bench.

I put entirely too much pressure on myself this week to MAKE MAKE MAKE with the time crunch & realized I was not having a great time at the bench. I am so stoked on this ski collection & it’s new one-of-a-kind designs, that didn’t want to rush or force it. So, I decided to reschedule to release it upon our return mid march! Making a ridiculous amount of pinecone necklaces- something I know so well & love so so much- felt like the perfect solution. I know it sounds weird, but being a jewelry conveyor belt in high stress times is the MOST SOOTHING THING.

TLDR: I’m releasing a TON of my classic pinecone necklaces tonight! The pictured Hemlock Cones & Conelets to be precise. 7PM EST IN THE SHOP! See you there.✌🏼

Photo dump of the past week of skiing in glades with gals & pups…before I inundate you with even MORE ski exciting content this week! 😉⛷️👀

Its truly a dream come true to FINALLY have a bevy of badass babes here in New England who love to shred the backcountry as much as I do. I am beyond grateful that we all met via the of @inclusiveskitouring Women’s Program this season & connected on the ‘gram. A handful of us skied a localish glade this weekend- we laughed as we stumbled up the mountain, gawked at rocks & mushrooms & pinecones along the way, watched the huskies rage in the snow & laughed even more as we forged entirely too many streams on skis.

And now I’m off to a new far away ski locale for the next 10 days…can anyone guess where it may be?! ⛷️🏔️

Ethereal Alaskan Landscapes✨

I figured I would begin the recap our big Alaska ski excursion with a few of the most otherworldly sights we bore witness to over the past 2 weeks. Starting with something I’ve longed for since I was a child: to see the magic of the Northern Lights in real life. When we saw the slight chance of viewing them in the Aurora Borealis forecaster midway through our trip, we jumped in the truck in the middle of the night & drove down the coast of the Turnagain Arm to this lookout, where we watched the lights dance- faint, albeit BREATHTAKING. We’ve never felt so giddy!

Other highlights include: skiing 6 miles out on a frozen lake to a vibrant glacier, watching the sunset illuminate an ocean full of icebergs as we touched down in Anchorage, skiing into the sunset over the Chugach Range, seeing the Turnagain Arm from above, watching the start of The Iditarod, the unreal view from our ski-in backcountry cabin and watching a fluffy Ptarmigan enjoy its life on a summit.

Needless to say, Alaska DELIVERED & I am replete with inspiration for my next collection- (which may or may not pay homage to the aurora. ✨)

More soon. Have you been to Alaska? What was the most incredible thing you witnessed? Or which of these wild sights is the most unbelievable to you?

We started off our Alaskan ski trip with a bang by skiing in giant packs to a remote backcountry hut tucked in the Chugach range. We spent the days climbing & skiing untouched swathes of pristine snow- & it was just as magical, challenging & rewarding as it sounds! Isaac & his best guy pals from college have had a tradition of going on a backcountry excursion every year since they met in 2009…& the annual tradition has been going strong ever since! However, now that they’ve been blessed with 3 equally adventurous women, we decided it was about damn time we got to partake in the fun! So, with our shared love for backcountry skiing, the six of us dreamed up this exciting AK excursion.

We climbed & skied a total of 20,000 ft of vert & 45 miles over the course of 7 ski tours in 3 mountain ranges. I’ve never been so tired yet so enamored with a landscape. I was the happy caboose for most of the climbs, as my pals are all mega athletes, but I made it to the top of every summit, & took lots of sneaky breaks to gawk at pines,  rocks & lichen (& survive. 😆) It was so nice to tuck into the hut each night to play banana grams, down stacks of Oreos, make whiskey snow slushes, & talk entirely too much about all of our dogs whilst tucked into our sleeping bags. It was a wild time & felt just like college again. Highly recommend dirtbagging with pals in the mountains. ⛷️

PLUS @stio spoiled us with the raddest ski kits for our trip! It’s no surprise that every piece absolutely delivered in quality, style & warmth after 10 days in the mtns. We’re rocking the Environ Bibs & I’m forever converted to being a bib girlie. No hiking up my pants after every run & super easy zips for ventilation & the facili-trees. 😜 I ADORE my Anorak XT jacket, emblazoned with pinecones & a joey pouch to collect real cones. I can’t recommend ‘em enough, & I’ve been a big fan even before working together!!

A trip down Flat Lay Memory Lane…

…as I impatiently wait for new silver & supplies to arrive so I can complete what’s on the bench!! Ahhh! 😅

I quit my job on a whim to start this metalsmithing endeavor back in early 2016, when flay lays & antique barn wood were all the rage on Insta & Pinterest. Turns out my millennial hipster self will forever love a good flat lay display, so it has become a tradition for every batch of jewelry I create. I mean HOW SATISFYING is it to see it all together? The hours upon hours of work, sore hands & torn up fingers are always worth it when the joy of the finished pieces eclipses the immense effort.

These ten snapshots represent the ebb and flow and evolution of my style and skills over the years. These photos are out of order, but for kicks, here are the years I created each collection: 1: 2017, 2: 2020, 3: 2016, 4: 2022, 5: 2021, 6 & 7: 2022, 8: 2018, 9 & 10: 2019.

So, the first photo is a BIG HINT as to what I’m creating right now- a style of jewelry I haven’t made since 2017. And after a myriad of requests over the years, I thought that it’s about damn time I bring it back. Any guesses?!

FACTS. 🐺🐺

A recreation of our viral reel from last summer, featuring a very Maine field of Lupines. 😍

We were young college kids, fresh off of a full summer working at a camp in the north woods. We had only been dating for two months, but were both pretty head-over-heels.

One Sunday, we were studying at a cute coffee shop in town. Even though we loved cozying up to get work done, I was super tired and complained the whole time. The shop felt too hot, my term paper felt too hard, my dress felt too tight. Fielding my complaints with the upmost patience, Isaac took me back to his dorm & loaned me an old pair of basketball shorts & a giant sweatshirt. I smeared off my makeup, threw my hair up in a messy tangle & continued to grumble about all my homework. As I sat cross legged on the floor, whining about this and that, he came up behind me, lifted me to my feet & spun me around.

“Laura I have something to tell you.”

“Ugh, what?”

“I love you.”

I was dumb struck.

“You love me? But I’m being a jerk & dressed like a slob.”

“Yes. I love you I love you I love you. In fact, I’ve been whispering it for weeks now, every time we said goodnight and you walked to your door. And I couldn’t wait any longer... I love you.”

Teary eyed, I replied,
“Me too.”

Happy birthday to my other half. I love you I love you I love you!! 🩵

pc: @photocait

One of my favorite ways to reset and spark inspiration after a big shop update is simply to play with stones. I love to create little assemblages of beautiful things and tiny bricolages until ideas come to fruition. As I poured over my stones today, dreaming up what I wanted to make next, I found myself drawn to my treasury of Royston Ribbon turquoise- many of these stones have been in my collection for years dating back to 2015...but as my work has shifted over the years, I’ve favored other materials, & let these beauties fall to the wayside, forgotten…but not for much longer.

Royston Ribbon Turquoise is quite unique as it is cut in the opposite direction of typical turquoise- each vein is sliced horizontally, as opposed to vertically, thus creating “ribbons” of saturated color. It’s always reminded me of rivers and seaside cliffs, swimming holes, lakeshores and tiny islands, meandering streams, oxbows and wetlands…basically all of my favorite places to spend hot summer days.

My goal this season has been to swim or dip in a wild body of water at twice a week. And so far I’ve kept that promise. To me, swimming is peak joy & the epitome of summer. So, I decided that my next collection will pay tribute to my favorite thing in the world: hot, sunny days spent on the lake, the sea or the river. Wearable reminders of summertime dips in crisp cool waters… listening to the water lap upon the shores of the lake, pines swaying above…tiny ways of preserving these memories year round. And each of these stunning stones will become a part of that.

Introducing The Summer Waters Collection- and the first two pieces to kick it off. A simple, elegant Lariat, and a bold pendant with drops of turquoise, like rainwater. Coming mid July.

SO, What pieces of jewelry would you like to see the rest of these stones become?! As always, I love your input as I begin to create!

I feel “stuck.”

Starting a brand new batch of work can be both thrilling & intimidating. In very rare form, I have a clean slate. Lingering orders have been shipped, supplies ordered & tools organized.

Depending on what mood I’m in, I’ll either be flush with inspiration and jump right into the work: feverishly sketching, compiling components, selecting the perfect stones…yet in other times, I just sit & stare (i.e. right now.) Mind blank. Overwhelmed with the sheer amount of potential possibilities. paralyzed by indecision. And then, if I’m not careful, I’ll let that tiny, mean voice in the back of my head convince me that I’ll no longer feel that creative spark again. That I’m a has-been. That every good idea has been had.

When that happens, I consult the “creative arsenal” that my friends & I have compiled over the years. We’ve made lists meant specifically to stoke the fire of inspiration. My personal go-to? Looking through past work.

These ten snapshots represent the ebb and flow of creativity, the evolution of my style and increase of skill over the years. From 2016-2023. Visual reminders that I *do* have good ideas & I *am* creative & I *can* be productive. This is the natural ebb & flow of creativity. A reminder that the ebb too shall pass, and the flow will return. Hope!

So, what are your tips & tricks for getting “unstuck” artistically? Any advice you’d offer a fellow creative?

TW: mental illness. ✨ Maine Midnight Danglers: Black Mica foraged from our land in Maine, suspended within a silver frame of stars. ✨
These earrings were a delightful challenge to build & I couldn’t be more thrilled to be bringing this year’s iterations to fruition. This particular pair was a game-changer for me last summer, as they represent a deeply personal breakthrough…

As some of you may know, I have Bipolar Disorder. I have found equilibrium through a regimen of therapy, medication, vulnerability with loved ones & an active lifestyle. However, it is incurable. I’ll always experience cycles of mania & depression, albeit now in much milder forms. Each summer, I typically experience a bout of hypomania (a mild manic episode) which is why my work & presence on here has been sporadic these past few weeks.

Life has been punctuated by difficulty focusing, a racing mind, paralyzing over-analyzation, increased energy, talkativeness, & productivity, higher self-confidence, & a flurry of inspiration. As always, some good, some bad. And If you know me well, you could tell. 😅

When I’m hypomanic, I find it particularly difficult to sleep. While I have medication specifically meant to help with sleep, I prefer to only use it when insomnia is insurmountable. Nature medicine first. I’ve found that what helps most is to simply stand beneath the night sky. I’ll step out onto our deck to admire the thousands of twinkling stars illuminating the night. With clear skies in Maine, the Milky Way is clearly visible, splashed across the horizon. It’s breathtaking, bestows calm, & most importantly, stirs slumber.

I created these mica earrings with that sight & feeling in mind. Nature has been key in providing stability for my mental health, & how lucky I am to be able to turn that inspiration into jewelry. And even more special? I now can source magnificent mica from our very own land here in Maine. 🤍

(I have entered this particular pair in @riogrande’s contest called the Summer Earring Challenge. It would mean so much to me if you could take a quick moment to vote for them! Follow the link in my bio & simply tap the 🤍. Share it too you feel so inclined! Thanks, friends!)

Did you know that Maine produces some of the FINEST tourmaline in the world!? And that much of it is mined down the road from us?!?! 🤯💎

I scored many of these incredibly vibrant & unique tourmaline slices on excursions in Poland, Newry & Bethel, Maine.

The darker of these slices hail from Mount Mica, the site of the first discovery of tourmaline in Maine back in 1820. Mt. Mica’s signature, is the confluence of black tourmaline (“schorl”) & green tourmaline (“verdilite.”) It is known for producing gems with delicate apple green shades- a hue that isn’t found anywhere else in the world! 🤯

And those pink fruit-like gems? They are cross sections of tourmaline crystals sliced horizontally, colloquially known as Watermelon Tourmaline! These crystals were first discovered in Maine in 1902 at the Dunton Quarry in Newry. 🍉

It’s no wonder that Maine’s state stone is Tourmaline! And did I mention this all is near our home?!?? 🤩

In designing a new batch of pieces featuring these fine Maine mined gems, I decided to start with what I know best…sawing & carving petite pines out of silver. They were the perfect “warm-up” for my hands as I dive back into metalsmithing after a summer hiatus. So happy to be back!

Tourmaline, along with a bevy of Maine mined minerals & Maine landscape inspired jewels will be available in my new collection, slated for early August. 💎🌲

(And if you ever find yourself in Bethel, Maine, treat yourself to a tour of the Maine Mineral & Gem Museum. You’ll soak up tons of knowledge on the science & history behind these crystals, & feast your eyes upon some of the finest specimens of tourmaline in the world! It’s unreal.)

2023 IS THE YEAR OF THE CHANTERELLE!! We’ve be graced with many massive Golden & vibrant orange Cinnabar Chanterelles in our woods & nearby trails this summer! The incessant rain has been good for one thing: it’s shaping up to be a foraging season for the books.

So, why the hype?? For starters, Chanterelles, (Cantharellus) are a coveted culinary delicacy, with a slightly sweet, buttery flavor. They are among the most desired mushrooms on the market, as they only grow wild! The single way to obtain these elusive trumpets is to foray into the forest during their short growing season. (Hence my obnoxious excitement July-Sept. 😆) They grow in moist areas by conifers, oaks & mixed forests. They’re mycorrhizal, meaning they grow in conjunction with trees. Goldens are most likely to grow around White Pines & Douglas Firs- serendipitously, my fav evergreens. 😭🌲

Chanterelles are a few inches tall & wide & range from pale yellow to dark gold. As they grow, they mature into vase shapes with silky smooth caps. Their stems are dense & fleshy with white insides, & even smell akin to apricots! The key characteristic setting them apart from poisonous look-a-likes are their signature false gills. These are forked ridges that appear to have melted onto the mushroom. For reference, common grocery shrooms with gills are white button mushrooms. Their underside frills are delicate & detach easily from the stem without causing damage to the rest of the mushroom, whereas false gills are unable to be detached from the stems.

If you want to add mushroom ID & foraging to your repertoire, I recommend the book, The Complete Mushroom Hunter by Gary Lincoff. I too have learned so much via @wildfoodlove & the blog Mushroom Appreciation. Another great resource is googling local foraging groups/classes in your area. I’ve been lucky to have been mentored by many experts through workshops over the years.

⚠️ DO NOT EAT any wild mushroom solely based upon 1 source on the internet!! ID with 100% certainty comes with experience, guidance from seasoned foragers & multiple sources. STAY SAFE, SMART & SUSTAINABLE!

Happy year of the Chanterelle! May your harvests be mindful & bountiful! 💃🏼🍄

BOONE’S THE BDAY BOY! 🎉

Our rambunctious, goofy & affectionate dude is two years old! In celebration of this momentous birthday, here are 10 baby Boone moments to induce all the feels & all the squeals.

ALSO: in honor of this boy’s bday, I thought it would be fun to ask y’all to share your favorite Boone memory! What’s a particular Boone Goon moment from real life or from IG that sticks out to ya? 👇🏻

Raising the bar with this new collection…💎😜

Gratuitous puns aside, I’m starting off the next batch of jewelry with what I reach for everyday: tiny natural turquoise necklaces. They’re fantastic, uncomplicated “warm-ups” for me as I dive back into metalsmithing.

As you can tell, I've fallen into an all-or-nothing posting pattern this summer. So many amazing things have & are happening, that I’m overwhelmed by the excitement of it all. In response, I either inundate y'all with updates OR go radio silent. Balance? Huh? What’s that?!

Why am I like this?! 😆

While I haven’t been productive in creating physical work or “content”, I have been quite productive in housekeeping…both literally & figuratively. Ideas have been formulated. Dots have been connected. The studio is shockingly immaculate.

I entered into a delayed Spring cleaning mode in July & haven’t stopped. I’ve organized, cleaned & rearranged nearly everything in our home. I’ve sorted through things that haven’t been touched in over a year. And, I’ve adulted hard. I balanced by Quickbooks, ordered supplies, restocked packaging materials & fixed that desk chair that’s been broken for monthssss. It’s been quiet work & SO SATISFYING. I’m set up for success until 2024. 

And yet, I still find myself frustrated with how it feels as if I don’t have much to “show for” all of this hard work. We’ve been conditioned to equate productivity with measurable success. However: play, rest, ideas, dreams, connection, conversation & community building, are PRODUCTIVITY. Essential, in fact. What other things would you add to this list?

TLDR: thanks for your patience & allowing me the space to get my ducks in a row this summer. I know it’s not as exciting as seeing new, finished jewelry, BUT a whole lotta that is coming real soon…ish. 😅🤞🏻

Last week of December:
-In a daze.
-Full of treats.
-Unsure of the day of the week.

Who else is currently in this state? 🙋‍♀️🤪

“You are too emotional”
“You don’t have it that bad”
“You are better off than that person”
“You are too much”
“You shouldn’t feel that way”
“You just need to be more positive”
“It’s all in your head”

...things you shouldn’t say to someone who struggles with anxiety/depression/mental illness. I’ve been told ALL these things by well meaning and not so well meaning people in my life. HOWEVER, what’s more important to note is that I have said all of these things to MYSELF for years. Especially 1, 2, 3 & 5. These limiting and dismissive statements prevented me from being vulnerable with others about my inner turmoil and delayed me seeking help...until things escalated out of control.

A few months into therapy, I reverted to my old patterns of these circulating thoughts. Through tears and with a little gentle coaxing, I revealed these dark statements to my therapist. She listened intently, paused, and asked “Would you say any of these things to a dear friend that was struggling?”

Absolutely not. Thanks to this gentle redirection by my therapist, there was a major shift my perspective. Her words have stuck with me ever since. Why do we put all of this pressure upon ourselves? Why do we torture ourselves and succumb to guilt and shame? Especially when it comes to our mental health?

Now, when I find my thoughts venturing into self deprecation, I’ve learned to ask myself that question. More often than not, it interrupts that downward spiral of negativity and helps me to redirect.

So let’s turn these statements around. What would you say to someone struggling with their mental health?

“You are worthy.”
“You are not weak for seeking help.”
“Your struggles are valid.”
“You are strong. You are capable.“
“It’s ok to feel the way you are feeling.”
“You are worthy of love.”

Can you repeat these things to yourself?
(Share any other encouraging reminders you repeat below:)
